title: Nを V (transitive)
explanation: を marks the direct object of a transitive verb.

title: Nをします
explanation: します takes a wide range of objects, meaning to perform the action expressed by the noun.

title: 何をしますか
explanation: Used to ask what someone will do or did.

examples.english: What will you do on Monday?

examples.japanese: きのう何をしましたか。
月曜日は何をしますか。
examples.english: On Monday, what will you do?

title: なん and なに
explanation: Both mean 'what.' なん is used before words starting with た・だ・な rows or before a counter suffix. なに is used otherwise.

examples.japanese: 寝るまえに、何と言いますか。
examples.english: What do you say before going to bed?

examples.japanese: テレサちゃんは何歳ですか。

title: N (place) で V
explanation: で marks the place where an action occurs.

examples.english: I buy the newspaper at the station.

title: Vませんか
explanation: Used to invite someone to do something.

examples.japanese: いっしょに京都へ行きませんか。
examples.english: Won’t you come to Kyoto with us?

title: Vましょう
explanation: Used when inviting someone positively to do something together. Also used when agreeing to an invitation.

examples.japanese: ちょっと休みましょう。
いっしょに昼ごはんを食べませんか。
examples.english: Won’t you have lunch with me?

title: お〜
explanation: お is a prefix showing respect or politeness. It is added to various words, such as [お]くに (country), [お]さけ (alcohol), [お]はなみ (cherry-blossom viewing). Some words are usually used with お even without special politeness, such as おちゃ (tea), おかね (money).
